text: If you run bash scripts in cron tasks, then all these decorations are useless to you, they can even create problems, so it is better to add them to the .bashrc file at a minimum. On the other hand, for working in the console, all sorts of decorations and shorthand commands can come in handy and can be added to .bash_profile.

author: @0x007A
text: For GNU/Linux when a user logs into the computer the .bash_profile is loaded and executed. The .bashrc file is loaded by .bash_profile using the same technique that you demonstrated although it only loads if the session is interactive.

author: @justray510
text: My .bashrc has 1 line = source .bash_profile. My .bash_profile sources different files to make any changes easy, it sources .aliases, .functions, .exports, .bash_prompt. This way when a login shell is ran or I sudo -s nothing changes and checking for root user always works for me. Also I noticed when Corey started a new login shell the same info was at the top of the window "last login blank blank blank. This can be made to go away by creating an empty file named .hushlogin. This idea came from GitHub.

text: So i went through these videos back when I had High Sierra. Long story short, wiped my hard drive, reinstalled and am now running Catalina. I'm finally able to edit the file successfully but:  Problem A: my old prompt edit (PS1="blablabla") from my last failed attempted, seems to STILL be there, even though I deleted the file and it's nowhere to be found.   Problem B: when I open terminal, the following message pops up: And this shows up even though I have LINE BY LINE the exact same text as the video shows. ".bash_profile: line 5: syntax error: unexpected end of file   The default interactive shell is now zsh. To update your account to use zsh, please run `chsh -s /bin/zsh`."   AAAnnnnnd problem C: Also when I open up terminal, the red circle in the top left corner (ie-the exit button) shows as if theres a process running (like and unsaved file). text: You should do another video for converting the .bash_profile and .bashrc to .zprofile and .zshrc. Ever since I did the MacOS Catalina update I have been having troubles linting my projects and running code with custom module imports due to zsh not finding my environment variables. author: @manwhoisDudeGuyBroMan
text: I ran into a problem and will share the solution incase anyone gets the same problem. ps i use Sublime Text 3 PROBLEM: puts command "if [ -f ~/.bashrc ]; then  source ~/.bashrc fi" and instead of its saying "from bashrc" it says error on line 5 or whatever  I GIVE SOLUTUON: place the command: "if [[ -f ~/.bashrc ]]; then  source ~/.bashrc fi" notice how this is a small difference but it works, there is merely extra square brackets but i find it works
